poem_title: A Grubstreet ELEGY On the supposed Death of PATRIGE THE Almanack-Maker. Anno. 1708.
author: Jonathan Swift

lines.line_text: WELL, 'tis as  has guest,
Tho' we all took it for a Jest:
is Dead, nay more, he dy'd
E'er he could prove the good  ly'd.
Strange, and Astrologer should Die,
Without one Wonder in the Sky;
Not one of all his  Stars,
To pay their Duty at his Hearse!
No Meteor, no Eclipse appear'd!
No Comet with a Flaming Beard!
The Sun has rose, and gone to Bed,
Just as if  were not Dead;
Nor hid himself behind the Moon,
To make a dreadful Night at Noon:
He at fit Periods walks through ,
Howe'er our Earthly Motion varies,
And 'twice a Year he'll cut th' ,
As if there had been no such Matter.

stanzas.stanza_text:
WELL, 'tis as  has guest,

is Dead, nay more, he dy'd

Strange, and Astrologer should Die,
Without one Wonder in the Sky;
Not one of all his  Stars,
To pay their Duty at his Hearse!
No Meteor, no Eclipse appear'd!
No Comet with a Flaming Beard!
The Sun has rose, and gone to Bed,
Just as if  were not Dead;
Nor hid himself behind the Moon,
To make a dreadful Night at Noon:
He at fit Periods walks through ,
Howe'er our Earthly Motion varies,
And 'twice a Year he'll cut th' ,
As if there had been no such Matter.

lines.line_text: SOME Wits have wondred what Analogy
There is 'twixt  and ;
How  made his  rise,
From a  to reach the Skies;
A  the Coblers Temples ties,
To keep the Hair out of their Eyes;
From whence 'tis plain the
That Princes wear derives from them;
And therefore  are now-a-days
Adorn'd with  and ,
which plainly shews the near Alliance
'Twixt  and the  .
BESIDES, that slow-pac'd Sign
As 'tis miscall'd, we know not who 'tis;
But  ended all Disputes,
He knew his Trade, and call'd it
THE  which heretofore
Upon their Shoes the  wore,
Whose Wideness kept their Toes from Corns,
And whence we claim our ,
Shews how the Art of  bears
A near Resemblance to the .

lines.line_text: A Scrap of  hung by ,
A great Refinement in ,
Can like the Stars foretel the Weather;
And what is  else but ?
Which an Astrologer might use,
Either for  or .

lines.line_text: THUS , by his Wit and Parts,
At once did Practice both these Arts:
And as the Boding Owl, or rather
The Bat, because her Wings are ,
Steals from her Private Cell by Night,
And flies about the Candle-Light;
So Learned  could as well
Creep in the Dark from  Cell,
And in his Fancy fly as far,
To peep upon a twinkling Star.

lines.line_text: BESIDES, he could confound the ,
And set the  by the Ears:
To shew his Skill, he  would join
To  in ,
Then call in  for Aid,
And Cure the Wounds that  made.

lines.line_text: GREAT Scholars have in  Read,
When  King of  was Dead,
His  and  did divide,
And each Part took a diff'rent Side;
rose a Star, the
Beneath, and mended Shoes in Hell.

lines.line_text: THUS  still shines in each Art,
The  and  Part,
And is  as good a Star,
As any of the  are.

lines.line_text: Star! Some Pity show
On  below,
Whom Roguish Boys in Stormy Nights
Torment, by pissing out their Lights;
Or thro' a Chink convey their Smoke,
Inclos'd  to Choke.

lines.line_text: THOU, high-exalted in thy Sphere,
May'st follow still thy Calling there.
To thee the  will lend his ,
By  newly Tann'd and Dry'd.
For thee they  Hulk will Tax,
And scrape her Pitchy Sides for .
Then  kindly Lends
Her Braided Hair to make thee ;
The Point of  Dart,
Turns to an  by Heav'nly Art;
And  wheedled by his Wife,
Will Forge for thee a ,
For want of Room by  Side,
She'll strain a Point, and sit astride,
To take thee kindly in ,
And then the  will be .
